description: Attested since about 1510, from Scots, perhaps from Middle Low German (Brunswick dialect) queer (“oblique, off-center”) (also compare with German quer (“diagonal”)), from Old Saxon thwerh, from Proto-West Germanic *þwerh, from Proto-Germanic *þwerhaz, from Proto-Indo-European *terkʷ- (“to turn, twist, wind”).
Compare Latin torqueō. Related to thwart. Began to be used to describe gay people in the late 1800s, see usage notes for more.

entries.meaning: (dated outside Scotland and Ulster) Weird, odd, or different; whimsical. [from 16th c.]
examples: “I wish I hadn’t cried so much!” said Alice, as she swam about, trying to find her way out. “I shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears! That will be a queer thing, to be sure! However, everything is queer to-day.”

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal, dated) Slightly unwell (mainly in "to feel queer"). [from 18th c.]
examples: "Well, I'm—I'm jiggered," said Peter, and his voice also sounded queer.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, sometimes derogatory) Non-heterosexual or non-cisgender: homosexual, bisexual, asexual, transgender, etc.
(broadly) Pertaining to sexual or gender behaviour or identity which does not conform to conventional heterosexual or cisgender norms, assumptions etc. [from 20th c.]

adverbs.description: queer (comparative more queer, superlative most queer)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, sometimes derogatory) A person who is or appears homosexual, or who has homosexual qualities.
(colloquial, sometimes derogatory) A person of any non-heterosexual sexuality or sexual identity.
(colloquial, sometimes derogatory) A person of any genderqueer identity.
examples: Gentrification often starts with the artists, revolutionaries, freaks, transfolks, and queers (what I would call my people) moving into poor neighborhoods inhabited by people of color.

verbs.description: queer (third-person singular simple present queers, present participle queering, simple past and past participle queered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To render an endeavor or agreement ineffective or null.
examples: I was a lot more apt to queer it than help it.
"But lor-a-mussy, Jacob, how could a woman get away from here with all her boxes in the middle of the night?"
"That's what queered me," and Spink slowly shook his head, "and queered a good many; for of course it got newsed about  […] "

entries.meaning: (slang, dated) To ridicule; to banter; to rally.
(slang, dated) To spoil the effect or success of, as by ridicule; to throw a wet blanket on; to spoil.
examples: "Food is what queered the party. We ordered a big supper to be sent up to the room about two o'clock. Alec didn't give the waiter a tip, so I guess the little bastard snitched."

entries.meaning: (social sciences) To reevaluate or reinterpret (a work) with an eye to sexual orientation and/or to gender, as by applying queer theory.
(slang, LGBT, neologism) To make a work more appealing or attractive to LGBT people, such as by not having strict genders for playable characters.
